content: You'll have to allow cookies in Thunderbird for the OAuth2 authentication to work. There is no point using a different browser.
creator: christ1

content:
The filter for an account is in a file named msgfilterrules.dat. The file is simple text and can be viewed/edited in Notepad. To get there,

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. you are now in the profile. EXIT thunderbird
  4. IMAP accounts are in imapmail folder and POP accounts in Mail folder
  5. open the file and view. It may be that there are different folders, different spelling for account, etc., that makes the filters not working. With careful editing you may be able to fix it.
creator: davidsk

If you're using Thunderbird version 140.x.xesr, you can drag-and-drop the folders in the folders list page to any order you like. But be careful! It's a delicate operation and it's easy to drop a folder into another folder rather than between them.

content:
How did you try to attach the photo? You should not need a helper application to *attach and send* files. That message appears when a user tries to *open* an attachment and Thunderbird does not know which application to open it with.

Following the error message anyway:

Go to Thunderbird settings > general > files & attachments. Is there a helper application listed for jpg files? If not, add one by opening a jpg attachment in a message, telling Thunderbird to open it, which application to use.

Now Thunderbird has an association between jpg files and a helper application. See if that makes a difference when you are trying to attach and send. I don't know why it would.

content:
If I could I would but the whole profile was already restored.

I restored the last ImportExportTools NG profile to get back up within an hour. As there hasn't been a crash in more years than I can remember IET was set to run once a week. The data on the crashed machine can be recovered, but no programs can run. The Windows partition won't boot either.

In the four days it took to get to this point the calendar had been updated and several hundred emails processed.

A transplant seemed at least a good idea to try and I don't see why T-Bird (same release on PC-A and PC-B) does not seem to care about the recovered files.

Also the ImportExportTools NG has been set to run DAILY and the whole-profile copies are being stored on another machine. I really try not to get burned the same way twice!

creator: rednoise

content:
I can't explain how filters could come and go like that, as it's never happened to me. But you can make recovery easier by backing up the filter files. Actually, you should consider making regular backups of you entire Thunderbird Profile, but if you're just interested in the filters, they are in files called "msgFilterRules.dat", one file in each account folder. For example, in Windows, with an IMAP account, the filter rules file would be found in:

C:\Users\<your logon name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<your Thunderbird profile>\ImapMail\<email account name>\msgFilterRules.dat

Make a copy of those files to a safe location and restore them when necessary, while Thunderbird is closed.

One thing occurs to me - could your antivirus be falsely flagging and quarantining them as virus/malware?
creator: rednoise
